Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The Solar Economy Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship (IGERT) project supports the development of a multidisciplinary, multi-institutional graduate training program of education and research in a sustainable solar economy at the Purdue University in collaboration with University of Delaware, University of Texas at El Paso, Sandia National Laboratory, the National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Fraunhofer Institute for Solar Energy Systems, Helmholtz Centre Berlin for Materials and Energy, Monash University and several industrial partners. We use the term "solar economy" to refer to a future state of affairs where nearly all the energy needed for electricity, transportation, heat, chemicals and food is based on sustainable supply of sunlight. To enable such a future state, this IGERT is primarily rooted in finding interdisciplinary technical solutions to the most important challenges of sun-to-electricity and sun-to-fuel within the context of harmonious coexistence with other uses of solar energy. In order to identify breakthrough technical solutions and gain a thorough insight into the complexity of a solar economy, a large number of interdisciplinary solutions will be generated and rapidly assessed for their system-wide impact. The IGERT establishes a new vision and program for integrating education and training that will reveal the complexity of this system to individuals from the diverse backgrounds necessary to address the future key energy challenges. The transition away from fossil fuels to a new solar economy necessitates major changes to the U.S. infrastructure and redefines the skill set required by our workforce. The IGERT program will address this need by developing lectures, course modules, training modules, and simulation tools that will define a new paradigm for interdisciplinary education and training in renewable energy. IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Solar Economy IGERT was a joint collaboration between Purdue University, University of Delaware and University of Texas at El Paso. The intentional collaboration was with scientist at Helmholtz-Zentrum für Materialien und Energie (HZB) in Berlin, Germany. The primary goal of the project was to train graduate students in the interdisciplinary research to enable emerging solar economy. The project trained 23 trainees and 20 associates and prepared a new generation of researchers, teachers, leaders and entrepreneurs who have a system-wide understanding of the complexities and constraints of our current energy economy as it continues to transition towards a renewable solar economy.

A hallmark of SEIGERT was to recruit cohorts from different departments such as chemical engineering, electrical engineering, material science and engineering, chemistry and economics and co-locate them to preform interdisciplinary research. This led to several firsts and publication of papers that would not have been feasible by researchers from any one department. Technology was developed to make thin-film solar cells through solution processing leading to 15% efficient Cu(In, Ga)(S,Se)2 and 9.4% Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 based solar cells. A new amine-thiol dissolution chemistry to prepare molecular precursors and associated thin-films was discovered. Solution processing was developed to prepare a series of semiconducting materials with earth abundant elements.  Through modelling, new insights were developed to increase fuel production from a given quantity of biomass. A new concept of ‘hydricity’ to coproduce hydrogen and electricity from solar thermal plants was introduced. This holds promise to be one of the most efficient methods to supply electricity around the clock using solar energy. Several policy papers were also published. In all, a total of 108 papers in highly cited journal were published, seven book chapters were written and 9 U.S. patent applications were filed.

The SEIGERT cohorts mentored several undergraduate researchers, learnt the art of teaching, developed training modules and simulation tools. Four new interdisciplinary courses were developed for SEIGERT and now with their continued offering they have been institutionalized. The cohorts attended several national and international conferences, made a total of 96 presentations and won multiple awards for their outstanding research performance. Some cohorts also received recognition for outstanding teaching and mentoring. The cohorts mentored several undergraduate researchers, some of whom became coauthors on the published papers. A large number of SEIGERT participants received training in the art of teaching, supervised classroom instructions and performed K-12 outreach activities.  Due to their expertise in one-of-its-kind system-wide energy analysis, the cohorts readily joined workforce in industry, national research labs and academia.

Indeed, with the education and training of 43 cohorts in the system wide ‘Energy’ concepts, the SEIGERT project has made a strong impact on the mission of the NSF’s IGERT program.
